sections.title: How We Want This To Feel
How We Care For Each Other

q01.title: Why I'm dating (right now)
q01.prompt: At this phase, I am dating because (choose any):
examples: Exploration: I'm seeing what is out there without pressure.
Discernment: I'm dating intentionally to see if we align.
Long-term potential: I'm looking for a serious partner.
Companionship: I enjoy shared time but not rushing.

q02.title: What feels comfortable right now
q02.prompt: Right now, I feel most comfortable when dating feels (choose any):
examples: Slow and intentional: we take time to build trust before escalating.
Warm but not intense: steady interest without pressure or love-bombing.
Structured but flexible: we make plans ahead of time and adjust as needed.
Playful and light: low-stakes fun while we learn each other.

q03.title: Too slow (for me)
q03.prompt: A pace that would feel too slow for me right now would look like:
examples: No momentum: Weeks between dates.
Vague plans: 'Let's hang sometime' but no date set.
Lack of depth: Only small talk after several dates.

q04.title: Too fast (for me)
q04.prompt: A pace that would feel too fast for me right now would look like:
examples: Forced exclusivity: Pressure to label it day one.
Love bombing: Intense praise/gifts too early.
Trauma dumping: Sharing deepest wounds on first date.

q05.title: Review point for clarity
q05.prompt: A healthy review point to revisit clarity (expectations, pacing, and whether we want a label) would be:

fields.label: What do you want this review to cover? (choose any)

options.label: Confirm or adjust our “focused on each other” agreement
When it feels natural and I notice a sign

fields.label: What sign would you notice?
fields.placeholder: Feeling ready to be more public, wanting more time together

examples: After 4 dates: Review expectations and physical boundaries.
After 1 month: Review exclusivity and communication style.
After first conflict: Review how we repair and move forward.

q06.title: Check-in cadence
q06.prompt: Ideal cadence and format for intentional check-ins:

fields.label: If something feels off, when do we talk about it? (choose one)

examples: Weekly: Sunday night check-in over tea.
Bi-weekly: Longer deep dive every other week.
As needed: We pause whenever one of us feels 'off'.

q07.title: Overwhelm pattern
q07.prompt: When I feel unsure or overwhelmed, I tend to (choose any) AND the best way to respond is:

fields.label: What I tend to do (choose any)
Please do NOT assume this means (optional)

examples: I pull inward: I go quiet and retreat. Best response: Sit close, stay calm, give me space without disappearing.
I seek reassurance: I ask 'are we okay?' because I feel uncertain. Best response: Say what you feel and where we stand.
I overthink: I analyze texts and tone until I spiral. Best response: Be clear and direct, name your intent, and clarify quickly.

q08.title: What safety means
q08.prompt: When I feel safe with you, it usually means (choose any) AND in my own words:

options.label: I feel free to change my mind
Conflict or discomfort won’t mean sudden abandonment

examples: Not rushed + free to change my mind: I can take time, say “not yet,” and you stay kind and steady.
Emotionally seen: You reflect what you heard before fixing it. I feel understood, not managed.
Conflict won’t mean abandonment: If we have tension, we pause and return, no threats, no disappearing.

q09.title: Support when stressed
q09.prompt: When I'm stressed, what helps most from you is:

options.label: Shift to something light and grounding

fields.label: If you only do one thing, do this:

examples: Listen: Just hear me out, don't fix.
Help: Take a task off my plate.
Space: Let me decompress alone for an hour.

q10.title: How to share the past
q10.prompt: When we talk about past relationships, I prefer:

options.label: Only if relevant to the present
Slowly over time as trust builds

examples: Slowly: Share stories as they become relevant.
Fully: Lay it all out so there are no surprises.
Relevance only: Only if it impacts us now.

q11.title: Affection that feels best right now
q11.prompt: Right now, the forms of affection that feel best to my nervous system are (choose any):
examples: Subtle touch: small grounding contact like a hand on the back or a light shoulder touch.
Hand holding: steady connection while walking or sitting, without escalation.
Forehead or nose contact: brief, gentle closeness that feels safe and slow.

q12.title: Approach for a kiss
q12.prompt: If you want to kiss me, the best approach is (choose one) plus what helps me feel safe in the moment:

options.label: Soft check-in ("I'd love to kiss you")
Nonverbal cue / pause and let me close the gap

fields.label: Words that land well for me (optional)
If I say 'not yet', the best next move is (optional)

examples: Ask directly: "Can I kiss you?"
Nonverbal cue / pause: lean in slightly and let me close the gap.
Soft check-in: "I'd love to kiss you" and wait for my signal.

q13.title: Overwhelm signs and best response
q13.prompt: If I start feeling overwhelmed during affection, my likely signs are (choose any). Then write the best response from you:

fields.label: Describe your other signs
fields.placeholder: I tend to fidget or change the subject

examples: Signs: I get quiet and go still. Best response: pause and ask, "Want to slow down?"
Signs: I smile but seem distant. Best response: gentle check-in and give space without offense.
Signs: I disconnect afterward. Best response: a calm follow-up like, "Anything feel too much?"

q14.title: Group settings preference
q14.prompt: In group settings (friends, etc.), I prefer we:

options.label: Mostly socialize separately and reconnect at the end

examples: Act as a quiet unit: we arrive together, stay mostly together, leave together.
Subtle check-ins throughout: we mingle, then reconnect every so often.
Physically subtle but emotionally aligned: you socialize, but we keep contact and touch base.

q15.title: Initiative and leadership
q15.prompt: Initiative feels best when (choose one), then add a short explanation so I can do it the way you actually mean it:

fields.label: One example that would feel great (optional):

examples: You plan/initiate more: you suggest most dates and lead next-step conversations.
It is 50/50: we alternate planning and follow-up.
It depends on the moment: whoever has more bandwidth leads that week.

q16.title: Chosen without pressure
q16.prompt: Something that helps me feel chosen without feeling pressured is:
examples: Consistency without demands: You make plans, follow through, and don’t guilt me if I need a slower pace.
Clear invitation, easy no: “I’d love to see you Friday. If you’re tired, no worries, we can pick another day.”
Affection without escalation: You show warmth (words, small gestures) without making it mean I owe you more.

q17.title: A fear I'm willing to name
q17.prompt: A fear I have about dating right now (that I'm willing to name) is:
examples: I'm afraid of getting attached and then being left.
I'm afraid of moving too fast and losing my pace or clarity.
I'm afraid I'm not enough or I'll be compared to someone else.

q18.title: How we treat this connection
q18.prompt: One sentence that describes how I want us to treat this connection is:
examples: With honesty and gentleness, even when it's awkward.
With consistency and respect for each other's pace.
With warmth, playfulness, and real intention.

q19.title: Top values (choose up to 5)
q19.prompt: Select and rank the values that feel most important to you in a relationship right now (up to 5). Drag to reorder by priority (top = most important).

fields.label: Select and rank your top values (top = most important)
Why these values matter most right now
fields.placeholder: Optional: share context about your priorities...

examples: Ranked: Faith > Integrity > Emotional safety > Family > Growth. Notes: I want spiritual alignment and steady trust before intensity.
Ranked: Emotional safety > Respect > Play/fun > Stability > Growth. Notes: I do best when home feels calm and kind, then we build.
Ranked: Family > Service > Faith > Integrity > Stability. Notes: I’m prioritizing a life-team mindset and reliability right now.

q20.title: Faith and church alignment
q20.prompt: At this stage, faith/church shows up best for me as (choose any):

options.label: Light conversation, keep it warm and simple

examples: Mutual support: encourage each other without policing or shaming.
Shared practice: attend church consistently and pray together sometimes.
Temple alignment: dating with temple marriage as the target.

q21.title: Physical boundaries and standards (right now)
q21.prompt: Right now, I want our physical boundaries to feel:

options.label: Slow by default; revisit if/when needed
I prefer not to detail everything, but I will say 'not yet' when needed

examples: Very clear boundaries: we talk explicitly about what is and is not okay right now.
Slow by default: assume slower progression, and check in before changing anything.
Simple "not yet": I can set a boundary and you accept it without debate.

q22.title: What “defining the relationship” means to me
q22.prompt: When we eventually define the relationship, for me that mainly means (choose any):

options.label: We use a public label (boyfriend/girlfriend, etc.)

examples: Exclusive and intentional: we are not dating others, and we act like it.
Focused but not labeled yet: we choose each other and see where it goes.
Still exploring: we are getting to know each other without promises yet.

q23.title: Future talk pacing
q23.prompt: Future talk (marriage/kids/life plans) feels best to me when:

options.label: Almost none right now; keep it present-focused
High-level only (values and direction, not timelines)
As it naturally comes up, with no pressure
At a structured checkpoint (after X weeks/dates)

examples: High-level only: values and direction, no timelines yet.
Some future talk: basics like marriage and kids, but keep it light.
Early and direct: I like talking about timelines and goals sooner.

q24.title: Roles and leadership expectations
q24.prompt: In a healthy relationship, I'm happiest when leadership looks like:

options.label: Shared leadership (both initiate, both carry load)
One tends to lead more, the other supports more
It depends on context (workload, season of life, stress)
Not sure yet; I want to learn this slowly

examples: Shared leadership: we both initiate, plan, and carry the relationship.
Complementary roles: one leads logistics, the other leads emotional check-ins.
Context-dependent: whoever has more capacity leads in that area.

q25.title: My conflict style under stress
q25.prompt: When I'm stressed or hurt, I tend to (choose any):
examples: Withdraw: I go quiet and need a little time before I can talk clearly.
Analyze + overexplain: I start problem-solving fast and want to talk through every detail to feel stable.
Seek closeness: I want reassurance first, then I can do the hard conversation.

q26.title: What helps me de-escalate
q26.prompt: If we feel tension, the fastest way for me to calm down is (choose any):

options.label: Physical grounding (walk, breathe, hold hands if safe)
Facts-only for a moment (no big emotions)

examples: Short break + validation first: Give me 15 minutes, then start with “I get why that hurt” before solutions.
Physical grounding: A slow walk and breathing helps me regulate more than sitting face-to-face.
Sleep then talk: If it's late, I calm down best by pausing and revisiting after rest.

q27.title: Apology and repair language
q27.prompt: Select and rank what makes an apology most meaningful to you. Drag to reorder by importance (top = most important).

options.label: A plan to do better next time

fields.label: What makes an apology feel genuine to you?
fields.placeholder: Optional: share what an ideal repair looks like...

examples: Acknowledgment of impact: "I see how that landed and I'm sorry."
Ownership and responsibility: "That was on me. I won't do that again."
Specific change plan: "Next time, I'll pause and ask before assuming."

q28.title: Not-okay conflict behaviors
q28.prompt: Conflict behaviors that are NOT okay for me (choose any) AND what I want us to do if one happens:

options.label: Threatening breakup to win an argument
Using the past as a weapon

fields.label: In the moment, I want us to (optional)

examples: Name-calling or insults: stop and reset, then repair before continuing.
Raised voice or threats: take a break until calm, then return to the topic.
Stonewalling: agree on a time to reconnect so it doesn't become avoidance.

q29.title: Heavy topics boundaries
q29.prompt: When discussing heavy topics (past, trauma, sensitive history), select and rank your preferences. Drag to reorder by importance (top = most important).

options.label: As needed, but pause at first overwhelm
I need heads-up before heavy topics

fields.label: What helps you stay regulated during hard conversations?
fields.placeholder: Optional: share what works for you...

examples: 1) Time-box it 2) Choose the right moment 3) End with reassurance/connection.
1) Heads-up first 2) Ask consent to talk 3) Take breaks if flooded.
1) No surprises in public 2) No late-night spirals 3) Reconnect before bed.

q30.title: Preferred repair ritual
q30.prompt: After a tough moment, the best 'repair ritual' for us would be (choose any):

options.label: Reconnect with gentle touch (if both want)
A short summary of what we learned

examples: Reconnect with gentle touch + one clear next step: Hold hands/hug, then agree on one change for next time.
Short summary + date reset: “Here's what I learned,” then a simple walk or dessert to reconnect.
Prayer/spiritual reset (if desired): A short prayer to re-center, then return with a softer tone.

q31.title: Ideal cadence for seeing each other (right now)
q31.prompt: Right now, a healthy cadence for seeing each other would be:

fields.label: Describe your schedule
fields.placeholder: Depends on my work schedule, we plan ahead

examples: 2 times per week: one planned date and one casual hangout.
3 to 4 times per week: short check-ins plus one longer date.
It varies: more when life is calm, less when school/work is heavy.

q32.title: Communication channel preferences
q32.prompt: At this stage, I prefer communication to be mostly:

options.label: Light texts + one call before dates
Texts most days + one call weekly
Mostly in-person; texts only to coordinate

fields.label: What does your mix look like? (1-2 sentences)
fields.placeholder: Quick texts most days, short call the day before we meet

examples: Text for logistics, call for feelings: quick texts, then a phone talk for depth.
Mostly in-person: keep important topics for face to face.
Mixed: voice notes during the day, then a nightly check-in.

q33.title: Privacy and sharing boundaries
q33.prompt: Regarding sharing our relationship with friends/social media, I prefer:

fields.label: Explain the context
fields.placeholder: Private at work, open with close friends

examples: Keep it private for now: no posts yet, and only tell a trusted person if needed.
Friends-only, low-key: tell close friends, no social media.
Open and normal (no secrecy): fine if it comes up naturally, no hiding.
Depends on context: private at work, open with close friends.

q34.title: Pace of integration (friends/family)
q34.prompt: Introducing deeper parts of life (close friends, family, routines) feels best when:
examples: Slow and gradual: meet close friends/family after trust is built.
As it naturally happens: integrate as opportunities arise.
After exclusivity: deeper integration once we have chosen each other.

q35.title: Jealousy triggers (if any)
q35.prompt: When I feel jealousy or insecurity, it's usually triggered by (choose any) AND what helps me most is:

fields.label: What helps most from you (1-2 sentences)

examples: Triggers: ambiguous plans. Helps: clear plans and a quick reassurance. Avoid: "you're being crazy."
Triggers: social media or mentions of past partners. Helps: transparency and empathy. Avoid: minimizing.
Triggers: sudden distance. Helps: a check-in and a reconnection plan. Avoid: disappearing.

q36.title: What reassurance works best
q36.prompt: Select and rank what helps most when you're feeling insecure. Drag to reorder by importance (top = helps most).

options.label: Clear words ("I like you, I'm here")

fields.label: Context about what helps vs. what doesn't
fields.placeholder: Optional: share more about what works for you...

examples: 1) Clear words 2) Concrete plans 3) Transparency 4) Gentle touch.
1) Space then reconnection 2) Clear words 3) Plans/time together.
1) Transparency 2) Plans 3) Clear words 4) Gentle touch.

q37.title: Exclusivity boundary preference
q37.prompt: At this stage, exclusivity feels healthiest when:

options.label: Not yet; we keep it open while exploring
We focus on each other without a formal label
We explicitly agree to be exclusive now
We decide at the review point (from earlier)

examples: Not yet: we keep it open while we get clarity.
Focus without label: we choose each other even if we do not name it yet.
Exclusive now: we agree clearly and act accordingly.

q38.title: Boundaries with other connections
q38.prompt: While we're exploring this, healthy boundaries with other people look like (choose any):

options.label: Friendships are fine; we keep them respectful

examples: No dating apps and avoid flirty texting with others.
No 1-on-1 dates with romantic intent, and we keep friendships respectful.
Transparency if someone pursues us, and we handle it as a team.

response_shape_hint.description: Recommended storage: responses keyed by respondent_id then question_id. Do not store names inside the questionnaire definition.

lite.title: Lite
lite.post_timebox_activity: Do something light and enjoyable (board game, dessert, short walk).

full.title: Full
full.post_timebox_activity: Stop and reconnect with play or rest. Do not keep analyzing.
